# D Proof of Theorem 2.B 

Proof. $\Leftrightarrow$ Consider a segmentation $\sigma \in \Sigma_{\Omega}(\mu)$ that is $\succsim_{\mathcal{R}}$-maximal but not strongly monotone. Thus, there exist at least two segments $p, \theta_{i} \in \operatorname{supp}\left(\sigma_{P}\right)$ such that $\max \operatorname{supp}(\sigma(\cdot \mid p))>$ $\theta_{i}>p$. We denote as $\theta^{\prime}$ the lowest type in the segment $p$ that is strictly above $\theta_{i}$, and as $\theta_{k}$ the maximal type in the segment $\theta_{i}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \theta^{\prime}=\min \left\{x \in \operatorname{supp}(\sigma(\cdot \mid p)) \mid x>\theta_{i}\right\} \\
& \theta_{k}=\max \operatorname{supp}\left(\sigma\left(\cdot \mid \theta_{i}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\varepsilon>0$ be sufficiently small and $r$ be the redistributive buyer transfer such that

$$
r\left(\theta_{i}, p\right)=r\left(\theta^{\prime}, \theta_{i}\right)=-r\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)=-r\left(\theta^{\prime}, p\right)=\varepsilon
$$

and $r=0$ otherwise. Neglecting for the moment the negative indirect impacts of $r$ by triggering a violation of the obedient constraint in the segment $\theta_{i}$, the direct impact on the welfare of types $\theta_{i}$ and $\theta^{\prime}$ involved in the transfer $r$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varepsilon\left[\left(w\left(\theta_{i}, p\right)-w\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right)-\left(w\left(\theta^{\prime}, p\right)-w\left(\theta^{\prime}, \theta_{i}\right)\right)\right] \\
>\varepsilon & \left.\varepsilon\left[\left(w\left(\theta_{i}, p\right)-w\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right)-\left(w\left(\theta_{i+1}, p\right)-w\left(\theta_{i+1}, \theta_{i}\right)\right)\right]>0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where both strict inequalities come from $w \in \overline{\mathcal{R}}$. In addition, given that $\sigma$ is $\succsim_{\mathcal{R}}$-maximal, $\sigma+r$ does not satisfy ( Ob ). In particular, there exists $\hat{\theta}$, with $\theta_{i}<\hat{\theta} \leq \theta^{\prime}$, such that $\hat{\theta} \in \mathcal{I}^{\sigma}\left(\theta_{i}\right)$ (see Appendix C for the definition of $\left.\mathcal{I}^{\sigma}(\theta)\right)$, and thus:

$$
\theta \sum_{x \geq \theta} \sigma(x, \theta)<\hat{\theta}\left(\sum_{x \geq \hat{\theta}} \sigma(x, \theta)+\varepsilon\right)
$$

To recover the obedience of the price recommendation $\theta_{i}$, we implement the transfer $t: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, which transfers a mass $\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon$ of buyers from $\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{i}\right)$ to $\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{k}\right)$ : that is,

$$
t\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{k}\right)=-t\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{i}\right)=\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon
$$

and $t=0$ otherwise. First, for sufficiently small $\varepsilon, \sigma+t \in \Delta(\Omega)$. Second, implementing $t$ cannot break any obedience constraints, and it corrects from any violation of obedience constraints induced by the transfer $r$. To see this, look at the difference between the profit made by setting the price $\theta_{i}$ and setting the price $q \geq \theta_{i+1}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \theta_{i}\left(\sum_{x \geq \theta_{i}} \sigma\left(x, \theta_{i}\right)-\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon\right)-q\left(\sum_{x \geq q} \sigma\left(x, \theta_{i}\right)+\varepsilon-\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon\right) \\
\geq & \varepsilon\left(\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}}\left(q-\theta_{i}\right)-q\right)=\varepsilon \frac{\theta_{i}\left(q-\theta_{i+1}\right)}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality follows from $\theta_{i}$ being an optimal price in segment $\theta_{i}$ according to $\sigma$, and the second inequality follows from $q \geq \theta_{i+1}$.

Therefore, $\sigma+r+t \in \Sigma_{\Omega}(\mu)$. The loss from the transfer $t$ is

$$
\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta} \varepsilon\left[w\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{i}\right)-w\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{k}\right)\right]
$$

Therefore, implementing the transfers $r$ and $t$ is beneficial if and only if $(5) \geq(7)$. If

$w$ is strongly redistributive, we have that $(6) \geq(7)$. Given that $(5) \geq(6)$, this ends the proof.
$\Rightarrow$ We prove the contrapositive. Suppose that $w \in \overline{\mathcal{R}}$ is not strongly redistributive. So there exist $p<\theta_{i}<\theta_{i+1} \leq \theta_{k}$, such that

$$
\left[w\left(\theta_{i}, p\right)-w\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right]-\left[w\left(\theta_{i+1}, p\right)-w\left(\theta_{i+1}, \theta_{i}\right)\right]<\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}}\left[w\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{i}\right)-w\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{k}\right)\right]
$$

Let $\mu \in \Delta\left(\left\{p, \theta_{i}, \theta_{i+1}, \theta_{k}\right\}\right)$ such that the unique strongly monotone and $\succsim_{\mathcal{R}}$-maximal segmentation, denoted $\sigma$, has three segments:

- one segment $p$ including all types $p$ and some type $\theta_{i}$;
- one segment $\theta_{i}$ including the remaining types $\theta_{i}$ and all types $\theta_{i+1}$;
- and one segment $\theta_{k}$ including all types $\theta_{k}$.

It is easy to show that such a $\mu$ exists. ${ }^{31}$ Let $\varepsilon>0$ be sufficiently small. We will now perform two transfers. The first one is a downward transfer $d$ defined by:

$$
d\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{i}\right)=-d\left(\theta_{k}, \theta_{k}\right)=\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon
$$

$d=0$ otherwise. The second transfer, $s$, is the reverse of a redistributive one. It is defined by:

$$
s\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)=s\left(\theta_{i+1}, p\right)=-s\left(\theta_{i+1}, \theta_{i}\right)=-s\left(\theta_{i}, p\right)-\varepsilon
$$

and $s=0$ otherwise. We check that $\sigma+d+s$ satisfies ( Ob$)$. First, for sufficiently small $\varepsilon$, this does not change the optimality of price $p$ in segment $p$. Second, in segment $\theta_{i}$, the transfers do not change the obedience constraint between for $\theta_{i+1}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta_{i}\left(\sigma\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}\right)+\sigma\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i+1}\right)+\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon\right) & -\theta_{i+1}\left(\sigma\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{i+1}\right)-\varepsilon+\frac{\theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{i}} \varepsilon\right) \\
& =\varepsilon\left(\frac{\theta_{i} \theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{1}}-\frac{\theta_{i} \theta_{i+1}}{\theta_{i+1}-\theta_{1}}\right) \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first equality follows from $\theta_{i+1}$ being an optimal price in segment $\theta_{i}$ for segmentation $\sigma$. Similarly, one can show that charging $\theta_{i}$ always gives a greater profit than charging $\theta_{k}$ if the segmentation is $\sigma+d+s$. Therefore $\sigma+d+s \in \Sigma_{\Omega}(\mu)$. Furthermore, it directly follows from Equation (8) that $\langle w, \sigma+d+s\rangle\rangle\langle w, \sigma\rangle$. Therefore, $\sigma$, which is the unique strongly monotone and $\succsim_{\mathcal{R}}$-maximal segmentation of $\mu$ (Lemma 4) is not optimal for $w$.

# E Proof of Lemma 4 

Proof. First, if the uniform price of $\mu$ is $\theta_{1}$, there exists a unique segmentation that is saturated, the one that does not segment the market. Suppose now that the uniform price of $\mu$ is strictly greater than $\theta_{1}$. Let $\sigma \in \Sigma_{\Omega}(\mu)$ be strongly monotone and saturated. Denote as $\theta_{k}$ the maximal type that is in the segment $\theta_{1}$. By Definition 1, there exists $\theta_{i}$, with $\theta_{1}<\theta_{i} \leq \theta_{k}$ such that $\theta_{i} \in \mathcal{I}_{\sigma}\left(\theta_{1}\right)$. Consequently, any segmentation that is strongly monotone and saturated must have the same market segment $\theta_{1}$. Conclude by iterating the same argument for the other segments.

## F Pseudo-code for the greedy redistributive algorithm

```
Algorithm 1 Greedy redistributive algorithm
    \(\sigma \leftarrow 0_{K \times K} ; \triangleright\) Initiates the segmentation as being the null matrix of size \(K \times K . \sigma_{i, j}\) denotes
    the element of \(\sigma\) in row \(i\) and column \(j\) and \(\sigma_{i, *}\) denotes the row \(i\) of \(\sigma\) seen as a vector in \(\mathbb{R}^{K}\).
    \(p \leftarrow 1 ; \quad \triangleright\) Initiate the counter of the market segments.
    \(\triangleright\) The next function returns the minimum among the optimal prices for the seller when facing
    a mass of consumers distributed according to \(\delta \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{K}\), to which we add a mass \(x\) of type \(k . \triangleleft\)
    function Optimal Price \((\delta, x, k)\)
    \(\delta_{k} \leftarrow \delta_{k}+x\)
    return \(\min \left\{\operatorname{argmax}\left\{\theta_{k}\left(\sum_{i=k}^{t} \delta_{i}\right): k \in\{1, \ldots, K\}\right\}\right\}\)
    for \(t=1\) to \(K\) do
    \(\triangleright\) Test whether allocating every type \(t\) to the segment \(p\) does not violate the obedience
        constraints for the seller.
    if \(p=\operatorname{Optimal} \operatorname{Price}\left(\sigma_{p, \bullet}, \mu_{t}, t\right)\) then
        \(\sigma_{p, t} \leftarrow \mu_{t} ; \quad \triangleright\) Allocate all the type \(t\) to the segment \(p\).
    else
        \(m=\max \left\{x: p=\right.\) Optimal Price \(\left.\left(\sigma_{p}, x, t\right)\right\} ; \triangleright\) Compute the maximal mass of type
        \(t\) that can be allocated to segment \(p\) without violating the obedience constraints.
        \(\sigma_{p, t} \leftarrow m ; \quad \triangleright\) Allocate this mass to segment \(p\).
        \(p \leftarrow t ; \quad \triangleright\) Initiate a new segment with price \(t\).
        \(\sigma_{p, t} \leftarrow \mu_{t}-m ; \quad \triangleright\) Allocate the remaining mass of type \(t\) to this new segment \(p\).
    return \(\sigma\)
```

abstract:
We study how to optimally segment monopolistic markets with a redistributive
objective. We characterize optimal redistributive segmentations and show that
they (i) induce the seller to price progressively, i.e., richer consumers pay
higher prices than poorer ones, and (ii) may not maximize consumer surplus,
instead granting extra profits to the monopolist. We further show that optimal
redistributive segmentations are implementable via price-based regulation.
